entry.title: Docker Container
entry.content:
I heard the words, container, and docker a lot. I know they refer to a tool related to Dev/Ops, but I never use one before. Recently I am writing a tool to find the best apartment (rent goes down since COVID19). Then I I think probably I should use docker in the apt finder project. This article is the first glimpse of docker. I would say itâ€™s magical.

And my friend said he can build an interface for the apartment app if I bake the code into a docker ğŸŒ

Whatâ€™s Docker?

Container is a solution of isolating & running different applications on the same infrasturcture.
https://www.docker.com/resources/what-container

Docker is a type of containers.

Tutorial

Full tutorial: https://www.docker.com/101-tutorial

Getting Start Container

  1. Create Dockerfile

    A Dockerfile is simply a text-based script of instructions that is used to create a container image.

  2. Run it!

    Running the new container in â€œdetachedâ€ mode (in the background) and creating a mapping between the hostâ€™s port 3000 to the containerâ€™s port 3000.

Updating App

  1. Change source code.

  2. Build new image.

  3. Find the old containerâ€™s id, stop it, remove it.

  4. Run the new image.

Sharing App

  1. Create repo on https://hub.docker.com/

    for example, 101-todo-app

  2. Login from local

  3. Give image a new name

  4. Push it.

  1. Running image on new instance

Persisting DB

to-do app as example. Docker will save data file on the host machine and make it available to the next container. Docker maintains the physical location on the disk and you only need to remember the name of the volume.

  1. create volume

  1. stop the previous todo app container

  2. Start a new todo app container with [-v]

  1. add items into todo list. then stop and remove the container.

  2. start a new container with the same run command above

  3. use docker volume inspect todo-db to check The Mountpoint is the actual location on the disk where the data is stored.

Reference

  • https://www.docker.com/101-tutorial

  • https://medium.com/@saschagrunert/demystifying-containers-part-i-kernel-space-2c53d6979504

  • https://www.docker.com/resources/what-container
entry.summary: I heard the words, container, and docker a lot. I know they refer to a tool related to Dev/Ops, but I never use one before. Recently I am writing a tool to find the best apartment (rent goes down since COVID19). Then I I think probably I should use docker in the apt finder project. This article is the first glimpse of docker. I would say itâ€™s magical.

entry.title: Closure and Decorator in Python
entry.content:
Closure

function wraps function. When you want to save state of a function but donâ€™t want to write a decent class, use closure.

then you can use it to count student amount of different classes:

When closure search a variables, Local -> enclosing -> global -> builtin.
In the example, total stores in enclosing level.

Decorator

Decorator wraps a closure with extra function, but wonâ€™t change the inner function, it returns a closure.
Example, logger

But decorated functionâ€™s function will become pretty confused about its identity. get_total.__name__ will return 'wrapper'.
Use @functools.wraps to preserve original function info.

Implement Singleton by Decorator

So the next step, is refactoring my report & log modules in the next sprint.
entry.summary:
Closure

function wraps function. When you want to save state of a function but donâ€™t want to write a decent class, use closure.
